Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Characterization of a BIoluminescence Reporter System for Mechanical Stress
Award.AbstractNarration: In this project, the PIs will investigate the relationship between mechanical properties of the cell and physiological response, using bioluminescence as a fast reporter of mechanosensitivity. Specific questions to be addressed are: (1) What are the mechanical properties of the cell? (2) How is mechanosensitivity related to the mechanical properties of the cell? and (3) What is the role of the cytoskeleton in determining the mechanical properties of cells and their physiological sensitivity? These issues will be studied in three species of dinoflagellates using atomic force microscopy to measure the elasticity of living cells and apply quantified mechanical stress to cells, microfluidics to subject cells to known levels of fluid shear stress, and laser confocal microscopy coupled with fluorescent probes to visualize the cytoskeleton. Pharmacological treatments that disrupt the cytoskeleton will be examined for their effect on cell elasticity and mechanosensitivity. This collaborative project applies advanced methods of physics, material science, and microfluidic technology to characterize the mechanical properties of the cell and the relationship to physiological sensitivity. The goal of the project is to enhance the value of dinoflagellate bioluminescence as a reporter of mechanical stress for applications in both the biological and physical sciences. This project will broaden the participation of underrepresented groups and advances discovery and understanding by providing internship opportunities to these undergraduate students through UCSD internship programs, the opportunity for a Ph.D. graduate student in the physical sciences to work in an interdisciplinary setting, and for two undergraduate students to participate as REU interns. The project advances discovery and understanding by contributing to the professional development of middle and high school science teachers by developing course materials through the Scripps Classroom Connection Summer Institute in partnership with COSEE CA, and providing demonstration kits of dinoflagellate bioluminescence to their students. Project results will be broadly disseminated through established scientific venues as well as education and public outreach activities through the Birch Aquarium at Scripps.

POR.DRECONTENT:
All organisms and individual cells experience mechanical stresses due to gravity, accelerations, and movement through viscous media. Eukaryotic cells are structurally sophisticated and can sense mechanical stimuli and respond to them, changing their physiology, gene expression, structural properties, and motility. Cell structure and mechanics play a role in the sensing and transduction of the mechanical stimuli and cellular responses to them. Planktonic marine protozoa dinoflagellates, which are unicellular organisms ~50 microns in size, respond to mechanical stresses in thier special way, by emitting flashes of luminescent light. This bioluminescent response is very rapid, occurring on 10 millisecond (ms) time scale, making it both a practical tool to visualize hydrodynamic stresses in flows and an appealing model to study cellular mechano-sensitivity and mechano-transduction. In this work, we tested the responses of individual dinoflagellates of the species Lingulodinium polyedrum to an abrupt exposure to hydrodynamic shear flow with a large shear stress. To this end, we designed and built a novel experimental system, which included a microfluidic device, a flow-driving setup, and a video-microscopy system with two cameras and a laser. This system made it possible to expose dinoflagellates to shear stress on a 10 ms scale, reliably detect luminescence flashes of rapidly moving cells with 5 ms resolution in time, and account for all cell passing through the field of view, whether luminescent or not. With this system, we established, for the first time, that as many as 40% of individual dinoflagellates exposed to hydrodynamic shear stress produce luminescent flashes after as short as 10 ms of exposure. In addition to providing quantitative data on the rate of mechanotranduction and biochemical response in cells, this result has a practical value for the visualization of flows using luminescent dinoflagellates. Notably, when the microtubule cytoskeleton of dinoflagellates was disrupted (with a drug oryzalin), only 23% of them flashed in response to shear stress, and the disruption of the actin cytoskeleton (with a drug  lantrunculin B) caused the proportion of the flashing cells to drop to 13%. These experiments showed that both microtubule and actin cytoskeletons play major roles in the mechanosensing of Lingulodinium polyedrum dinoflagellates. This finding may have broader implications and apply to mechano-sensing and mechano-transduction in other types of cells.

When building the microfluidic devices for the project with UV-photolithography, we realized that our existing commercial UV light source based on a broad-band mercury lamp with limited collimation was inadequate for this purpose. Therefore, we designed and built a novel UV light source based on an array of high-luminosity UV light emitting diodes (LEDs), which had recently become available. The narrow spectrum and better collimation of the UV light of the LED light source resulted in a substantial improvement in the quality of production of the microfluidic devices. The UV light source that we built turned out to be substantially more stable, reliable, and easier to use for general microfabrication tasks that the commercial setup. In addition, the costs of supplies, materials, and machining for building the LED UV light source are low and it is nearly maintenance-free. The UV LED light source is also very much “green”, eliminating hazardous mercury lamps and reducing the annual energy consumption from 4000 kWh (for the mercury lamp UV-sources) to <2 kWh. This UV LED light source is ideally suited for microfabrication in academic research laboratories and small companies. After the paper describing this light source was published in 2015, it has been replicated in, at least, two other university laboratories in the US, and a modified version of the light source has been built for the Quantitative Biology teaching laboratory at UCSD.

The NSF funding provided the opportunities for two graduate students to get training and experience in microfabrication and micromachining, in design, construction, and troubleshooting of opto-mechanical systems, in design and operation of the experimental setups, involving microfluidics, optics, and microscopy, and in experiments with live cells.
